First of all, bipedal dinosaurs on this planet have almost evolved three legs, with their tail acting to balance them like a tripod. I think that's also true for kangaroos. What if such a tail were to become like a springboard to propel the animal, so it could hop? It would then be acting as a leg. Also, spider monkeys have a really prehensile tail which is like an extra limb. If such a structure evolved so it could also bear weight, it would be a leg. In addition, imagine how a person moves on crutches using a tripod form of locomotion. A three-legged animal could use a similar kind of gait. 
 
 From a developmental standpoint, three legs could easily evolve in a radially symmetrical animal. In a bilateral animal it would be more problematical, as the third leg would probably evolve from a midline structure, like tail. Well, I'm all out of ideas for the moment.

 Sensory aparatus is crucial, from a biological point of view. And using our only data point, Earth, it's good to have them focused mainly in one direction; the front of the animal. If you have a front and back, that argues for symmetry based on a power of two, which would preclude having three legs. So I would predict that any creature advanced enough to have higher level sensory organs would have an even number of legs.

 think about locomotion and how it works. with 2 leg locomotion, both legs move alternately, with the center of gravity moving forward just enough to be supported by the time the moving leg lands, and the supporting leg moves forward. with 3 legged locomotion, either each leg moves in turn, causing the animal to be constantly spinning and not really moving in any direction, or 1 leg would move by itself, and the 2 others moving at the same time. the single leg would ned to be twice as strong as the other 2, because it supports twice as much weight when the other 2 legs are moving forward, otherwise this create would have a hard time moving. the limb structure for this third leg would also have to be very different, as well as muscle build. also, this design would do terribly for going up or down hills. going up a hill, the center of gravity of the animal would have to be far forward or the animal wwill fall backwards down the hill. but leaning forward this far would cause the middle leg tohave to extend to far while supporting the weight while the other two legs moved. all in all, its a really inferior design to a two legged animal where each leg has equal work and range of motion.
